entry.title: æ“ä½œç³»ç»ŸåŽŸç†ï¼šLinux Commands
entry.content: æ‘˜è¦ Linux Commands | Linux å¸¸ç”¨å‘½ä»¤ Learn By Example æŸ¥çœ‹ç¡¬ä»¶ä¿¡æ¯1234567891011$ lscpu$ cat /proc/cpuinfo$ cat /proc/cpuinfo | grep 'processor' | wc -l # é€»è¾‘CPUä¸ªæ•°$ cat /proc/cpuinfo | grep 'physical id' | sort | uniq | wc -l # ç‰©ç†CPUä¸ªæ•°$ cat /proc/cpuinfo | grep 'cpu cores' | wc -l # æ¯ä¸ªç‰©ç†CPUä¸­Coreçš„ä¸ªæ•°$ cat /proc/meminfo$ fdisk -l$ ifconfig -a$ lspci$ dmidecode -t bios$ dmidecode -q Learn By Example Command-line-text-processing 1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526$ echo 'foo:123:bar:789' | awk -F: '{print $2,$3}'123 bar$ # second field where input field separator is :$ echo 'foo:123:bar:789' | awk -F: '{print $2}'123$ # last field$ echo 'foo:123:bar:789' | awk -F: '{print $NF}'789$ # first and last field$ # note the use of , and space between output fields$ echo 'foo:123:bar:789' | awk -F: '{print $1, $NF}'foo 789$ # second last field$ echo 'foo:123:bar:789' | awk -F: '{print $(NF-1)}'bar$ # use quotes to avoid clashes with shell special characters$ echo 'one;two;three;four' | awk -F';' '{print $3}'three$ echo 'Sample123string54with908numbers' | awk -F'[0-9]+' '{print $2}'string more details:Shell startup scripts AWK in 20 minutes Ten Things I Wish Iâ€™d Known About bash Linux CommandsåŽŸæ–‡ï¼šhttps://www.howtoforge.com/linux-commands/ æœ¬æ–‡çš„ç‰¹ç‚¹æ˜¯éžå¸¸ç®€æ´ï¼Œå°†ç¹æ‚çš„Linuxå‘½ä»¤è¡Œç­›é€‰å‡º100æ¡å·¦å³ï¼Œéžå¸¸é€‚åˆå…¥é—¨å­¦ä¹ ã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼Œå°†é¢†åŸŸçŸ¥è¯†ä»¥â€œæ¡ç›®+ç¤ºä¾‹â€çš„æ–¹å¼æ¥æ•´ç†ï¼Œç±»ä¼¼ç¼–å­—å…¸ä¸€æ ·ï¼Œåœ¨ç¼–è¾‘çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­å¯ä»¥ä¿ƒè¿›å­¦ä¹ è€…åŠ æ·±è®¤è¯†ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ–¹ä¾¿æ—¥åŽæŒç»­æ”¹è¿›ï¼ˆå¢žåŠ æ³¨è§£ã€å‚è€ƒæ–‡çŒ®ã€ç´¢å¼•ç­‰ï¼‰ï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸€ç§ä¸é”™çš„å­¦ä¹ æ–¹æ³•ã€‚æœ€åŽï¼Œæ•´ç†è¿™äº›å‘½ä»¤è¡Œçš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œæˆ‘ä½“ä¼šåˆ°æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿæœ€é‡è¦çš„å·¥ä½œå®žé™…å°±æ˜¯å¯¹æ–‡ä»¶çš„ç®¡ç†ï¼Œåˆ›å»ºã€ç§»åŠ¨ã€æŸ¥çœ‹ã€ç¼–è¾‘ã€é”€æ¯ã€æ£€ç´¢ï¼Œéƒ½æ˜¯å›´ç»•æ–‡ä»¶çš„æ“ä½œï¼Œäº‹å®žä¸Šä¹Ÿæ˜¯å®žé™…å·¥ä½œä¸­ä½¿ç”¨æœ€é¢‘ç¹çš„éœ€æ±‚ã€‚å¯¹å¼€å‘è€…æ¥è¯´ï¼Œä»¥Linuxå‘½ä»¤è¡Œä¸ºæ¨¡ç‰ˆï¼Œå‘½åé£Žæ ¼ã€äººæœºäº¤äº’ã€å°è€Œç¾Žçš„å®žçŽ°æ–¹å¼ï¼Œä¿ƒè¿›è‡ªå·±åœ¨å…¶å®ƒé¢†åŸŸçš„åº”ç”¨ã€æé«˜å¤§æœ‰è£¨ç›Šã€‚ Adduser/Addgroupåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæƒé™ç®¡ç†ï¼›å¢žåŠ ç”¨æˆ·ã€ç”¨æˆ·ç»„ The adduser and addgroup commands lets you add a new user and group to a system, respectively. Hereâ€™s an example for adduser:1234567$ sudo adduser testuserAdding user `testuser' ...Adding new group `testuser' (1003) ...Adding new user `testuser' (1003) with group `testuser' ...Creating home directory `/home/testuser' ...Copying files from `/etc/skel' ...Enter new UNIX password: Archåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç³»ç»Ÿä¿¡æ¯ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹CPUæž¶æž„ The arch command is used to print the machineâ€™s architecture. For example:123$ archi686Not sure what 'i686' means? Head here. Cal/Ncalåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç³»ç»Ÿä¿¡æ¯ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹æ—¥åŽ† The cal and ncal commands display a calendar in the output.123456789101112131415161718$ calMarch 2017Su Mo Tu We Th Fr Sa1 2 3 45 6 7 8 9 10 1112 13 14 15 16 17 1819 20 21 22 23 24 2526 27 28 29 30 31$ ncalMarch 2017Su 5 12 19 26Mo 6 13 20 27Tu 7 14 21 28We 1 8 15 22 29Th 2 9 16 23 30Fr 3 10 17 24 31Sa 4 11 18 25 Catåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹æ–‡ä»¶å†…å®¹The cat command allows you to concatenate files, or data provided on standard input, and print it on the standard output. In layman terms, the command prints the information provided to it, whether through stdin or in the form a file.12$ cat test.txtHello...how are you? Cdåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›åˆ‡æ¢å·¥ä½œç›®å½•The cd command is used to change userâ€™s present working directory.1$ cd /home/himanshu/ Chgrpåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ã€æƒé™ç®¡ç†ï¼›åˆ‡æ¢æ–‡ä»¶æ‰€å±žç»„The chgrp command allows you to change the group ownership of a file. The command expects new group name as its first argument and the name of file (whose group is being changed) as second argument.1$ chgrp howtoforge test.txt Chmodåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ã€æƒé™ç®¡ç†ï¼›åˆ‡æ¢æ–‡ä»¶æ‰§è¡Œæƒé™The chmod command lets you change access permissions for a file. For example, if you have a binary file (say helloWorld), and you want to make it executable, you can run the following command:1chmod +x helloWorld Chownåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ã€æƒé™ç®¡ç†ï¼›åˆ‡æ¢æ–‡ä»¶æ‰€æœ‰è€…The chown command allows you to change the ownership and group of a file. For example, to change the owner of a file test.txt to root, as well as set its group as root, execute the following command:1chown root:root test.txt Cksumåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹æ–‡ä»¶å±žæ€§The cksum command prints the CRC checksum and byte count for the input file.123$ cksum test.txt3741370333 20 test.txtNot sure what checksum is? Head here. Clearåˆ†ç±»ï¼šäººæœºäº¤äº’ï¼›æ¸…å±The clear command is used to clear the terminal screen.1$ clear Cmpåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æ–‡ä»¶æ¯”å¯¹ byte-by-byteThe cmp command is used to perform byte-by-byte comparison of two files.12$ cmp file1 file2file1 file2 differ: byte 1, line 1 Commåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æ–‡ä»¶æ¯”å¯¹The comm command is used to compare two sorted files line-by-line. For example, if â€˜file1â€™ contains numbers 1-5 and â€˜file2â€™ contains number 4-8, hereâ€™s what the â€˜commâ€™ command produces in this case:1$ comm file1 file2 æ”¯æŒé€‰é¡¹ï¼š123-1ï¼šä¸æ˜¾ç¤ºåœ¨ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæ–‡ä»¶å‡ºçŽ°çš„å†…å®¹ï¼›-2ï¼šä¸æ˜¾ç¤ºåœ¨ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªæ–‡ä»¶ä¸­å‡ºçŽ°çš„å†…å®¹ï¼›-3ï¼šä¸æ˜¾ç¤ºåŒæ—¶åœ¨ä¸¤ä¸ªæ–‡ä»¶ä¸­éƒ½å‡ºçŽ°çš„å†…å®¹ã€‚ Cpåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æ–‡ä»¶å¤åˆ¶The cp command is used for copying files and directories.1$ cp test.txt /home//himanshu/Desktop/ Csplitåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›å¾…è¡¥å……å†…å®¹The csplit command lets you split a file into sections determined by context lines. For example, to split a file into two where the first part contains â€˜n-1â€™ lines and the second contains the rest, use the following command: 1$ csplit file1 [n] The two parts are saved as files with names â€˜xx00â€™ and â€˜xx01â€™, respectively. Dateåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç³»ç»Ÿä¿¡æ¯ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹ç³»ç»Ÿæ—¶é—´The date command can be used to print (or even set) the system date and time.12$ dateTue Feb 28 17:14:57 IST 2017 Ddåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›å¾…è¡¥å……å†…å®¹The dd command copies a file, converting and formatting according to the operands. For example, the following command creates an image of /dev/sda partition.1dd if=/dev/sda of=/tmp/dev-sda-part.img Dfåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹æ–‡ä»¶ç³»ç»Ÿåˆ©ç”¨çŽ‡The df command displays the file system disk space usage in output.123$ df /dev/sda1Filesystem 1K-blocks Used Available Use% Mounted on/dev/sda1 74985616 48138832 23014620 68% / Diffåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æ–‡ä»¶æ¯”å¯¹ line-by-lineThe diff command lets you compare two files line by line.1$ diff file1 file2 Diff3åˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æ–‡ä»¶æ¯”å¯¹,ä¸‰ä¸ªæ–‡ä»¶The diff3 command, as the name suggests, allows you to compare three files line by line.1diff3 file1 file2 file3 Diråˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹å½“å‰ç›®å½•æ–‡ä»¶åˆ—è¡¨The dir command lists directory contents. For example:12$ dirtest1 test2 test.7z test.zip Dirnameåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹å½“å‰ç›®å½•The dirname command strips last component from a file name/path. In laymanâ€™s terms, you can think of it as a tool that, for example, removes file name from the fileâ€™s absolute path.12$ dirname /home/himanshu/file1/home/himanshu Dmidecodeåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç³»ç»Ÿä¿¡æ¯ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹ç¡¬ä»¶ä¿¡æ¯ The dmidecode command prints a systemâ€™s DMI (aka SMBIOS) table contents in a human-readable format.12345678910111213$ sudo dmidecode# dmidecode 2.12SMBIOS 2.6 present.50 structures occupying 2056 bytes.Table at 0x000FCCA0.Handle 0x0000, DMI type 0, 24 bytesBIOS InformationVendor: American Megatrends Inc.Version: 080015Release Date: 08/22/2011......... DMI (Desktop Management Interface, DMI)å°±æ˜¯å¸®åŠ©æ”¶é›†ç”µè„‘ç³»ç»Ÿä¿¡æ¯çš„ç®¡ç†ç³»ç»Ÿï¼ŒDMIä¿¡æ¯çš„æ”¶é›†å¿…é¡»åœ¨ä¸¥æ ¼éµç…§SMBIOSè§„èŒƒçš„å‰æä¸‹è¿›è¡Œã€‚ SMBIOS(System Management BIOS)æ˜¯ä¸»æ¿æˆ–ç³»ç»Ÿåˆ¶é€ è€…ä»¥æ ‡å‡†æ ¼å¼æ˜¾ç¤ºäº§å“ç®¡ç†ä¿¡æ¯æ‰€éœ€éµå¾ªçš„ç»Ÿä¸€è§„èŒƒã€‚SMBIOSå’ŒDMIæ˜¯ç”±è¡Œä¸šæŒ‡å¯¼æœºæž„Desktop Management Task Force (DMTF)èµ·è‰çš„å¼€æ”¾æ€§çš„æŠ€æœ¯æ ‡å‡†ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­DMIè®¾è®¡é€‚ç”¨äºŽä»»ä½•çš„å¹³å°å’Œæ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿã€‚ Duåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹æŒ‡å®šç›®å½•ç£ç›˜åˆ©ç”¨çŽ‡The du command displays disk usage of files present in a directory as well as its sub-directories.123456789$ du /home/himanshu/Desktop/92 /home/himanshu/Desktop/Downloads/meld/meld/ui88 /home/himanshu/Desktop/Downloads/meld/meld/vc56 /home/himanshu/Desktop/Downloads/meld/meld/matchers12 /home/himanshu/Desktop/Downloads/meld/meld/__pycache__688 /home/himanshu/Desktop/Downloads/meld/meld16 /home/himanshu/Desktop/Downloads/meld/bin328 /home/himanshu/Desktop/Downloads/meld/data/ui52 /home/himanshu/Desktop/Downloads/meld/data/icons/svg EchoThe echo command displays whatever input text is given to it.12$ echo hello hihello hi Edåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›ç¼–è¾‘å™¨ed is a line-oriented text editor.1$ ed å•è¡Œçº¯æ–‡æœ¬ç¼–è¾‘å™¨ï¼Œå®ƒæœ‰å‘½ä»¤æ¨¡å¼ï¼ˆcommand modeï¼‰å’Œè¾“å…¥æ¨¡å¼ï¼ˆinput modeï¼‰ä¸¤ç§å·¥ä½œæ¨¡å¼ã€‚æ”¯æŒé€‰é¡¹ï¼š1234567Aï¼šåˆ‡æ¢åˆ°è¾“å…¥æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œåœ¨æ–‡ä»¶çš„æœ€åŽä¸€è¡Œä¹‹åŽè¾“å…¥æ–°çš„å†…å®¹ï¼›Cï¼šåˆ‡æ¢åˆ°è¾“å…¥æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œç”¨è¾“å…¥çš„å†…å®¹æ›¿æ¢æŽ‰æœ€åŽä¸€è¡Œçš„å†…å®¹ï¼›iï¼šåˆ‡æ¢åˆ°è¾“å…¥æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œåœ¨å½“å‰è¡Œä¹‹å‰åŠ å…¥ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„ç©ºè¡Œæ¥è¾“å…¥å†…å®¹ï¼›dï¼šç”¨äºŽåˆ é™¤æœ€åŽä¸€è¡Œæ–‡æœ¬å†…å®¹ï¼›nï¼šç”¨äºŽæ˜¾ç¤ºæœ€åŽä¸€è¡Œçš„è¡Œå·å’Œå†…å®¹ï¼›wï¼š<æ–‡ä»¶å>ï¼šä¸€ç»™å®šçš„æ–‡ä»¶åä¿å­˜å½“å‰æ­£åœ¨ç¼–è¾‘çš„æ–‡ä»¶ï¼›qï¼šé€€å‡ºedç¼–è¾‘å™¨ã€‚ Ejectåˆ†ç±»ï¼šåª’ä½“ç®¡ç†ï¼›å¸è½½The eject command lets you eject removable media (typically, a CD ROM or floppy disk)1$ eject Envåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç³»ç»Ÿä¿¡æ¯ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹ç”¨æˆ·çŽ¯å¢ƒå˜é‡The env command not only displays the current environment, but also lets you edit it.1$ env Exitåˆ†ç±»ï¼šäº¤äº’ï¼›é€€å‡ºThe exit command causes the shell to exit.1$ exit Expandåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›ç¼–è¾‘å™¨ï¼›å°†TABç¬¦æ›¿æ¢ä¸ºç©ºæ ¼ç¬¦The expand command converts tabs present in the input file(s) into spaces, and writes the file contents to standard output.1$ expand file1 Expråˆ†ç±»ï¼šè®¡ç®—å™¨ï¼›è¡¨è¾¾å¼The expr command evaluates expressions. For example:12$ expr 1 + 23 Factoråˆ†ç±»ï¼šè®¡ç®—å™¨ï¼›åˆ†è§£è´¨å› æ•°The factor command prints the prime factors of the input number.12$ factor 135135: 3 3 3 5 Fgrepåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æœç´¢ï¼›åŒ¹é…æŒ‡å®šæ–‡ä»¶å­—ç¬¦ The fgrep command is equivalent to the grep command when executed with the -F command line option. The tool is also known as fixed or fast grep as it doesnâ€™t treat regular expression metacharacters as special, processing the information as simple string instead. For example, if you want to search for dot (.) in a file, and donâ€™t want grep to interpret it as a wildcard character, use fgrep in the following way:1$ fgrep "." [file-name] Findåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æœç´¢ï¼›The find command lets you search for files in a directory as well as its sub-directories.123456789101112$ find test*testtest1test2test.7ztest.ctest.txtMore examples for the Linux Find command:* 14 Practical Examples of Linux Find Command for Beginners* Searching For Files And Folders With The find Command* Finding Files On The Command Line Fmtåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›è¯»å–æ–‡ä»¶å†…å®¹å¹¶æ ¼å¼åŒ–è¾“å‡ºï¼ˆæŸ¥çœ‹æ”¯æŒé€‰é¡¹ï¼‰fmt is a simple optimal text formatter. It reformats each paragraph in the file passed to it, and writes the file contents to standard output.1$ fmt file1 Foldåˆ†ç±»ï¼šäº¤äº’ï¼›æŽ§åˆ¶æ–‡ä»¶å†…å®¹è¾“å‡ºæ—¶æ‰€å ç”¨çš„å±å¹•å®½åº¦ The fold command wraps each input line to fit in specified width.12345$ fold -w 10Hi my name is himanshu AroraHi my nameis himanshu Arora Freeåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç³»ç»Ÿä¿¡æ¯ï¼›æ€§èƒ½ç›‘æµ‹ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹å†…å­˜åˆ©ç”¨æƒ…å†µã€‚è¯¦ç»†ä»‹ç» >>>more>>>The free command displays the amount of free and used memory in the system.12345$ free total used free shared buffers cachedMem: 1800032 1355288 444744 79440 9068 216236-/+ buffers/cache: 1129984 670048Swap: 1832956 995076 837880 Linux æ€§èƒ½è¯Šæ–­:è´Ÿè½½è¯„ä¼° Linux æ€§èƒ½è¯Šæ–­:å¿«é€Ÿæ£€æŸ¥å•(Netflixç‰ˆ) æ“ä½œç³»ç»ŸåŽŸç† | How Linux Worksï¼ˆä¸‰ï¼‰ï¼šMemory Grepåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æœç´¢ï¼›The grep command searches for a specified pattern in a file (or files) and displays in output lines containing that pattern.12345678$ grep Hello test.txtHello...how are you?More tutorials and examples for the Linux Grep command:* How to use grep to search for strings in files on the shell* How to perform pattern search in files using Grep$ grep -r test /usr Groupsåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æœç´¢ï¼›The groups command displays the name of groups a user is part of.12$ groups himanshuhimanshu : himanshu adm cdrom sudo dip plugdev lpadmin sambashare Gzipåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›åŽ‹ç¼©The gzip command compresses the input file, replacing the file itself with one having a .gz extension.1$ gzip file1 Gunzipåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›è§£åŽ‹ç¼©Files compressed with gzip command can be restored to their original form using the gunzip command.1$ gunzip file1.gz Headåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹æ–‡ä»¶The head command displays the first 10 lines of the file to standard output1234567891011$ head CHANGELOG.txtBEEBEEP (Secure Lan Messanger)BeeBEEP2.0.4- Some GUI improvements (new icons, file sharing tree load faster)- Always Beep on new message arrived (option)- Favorite users (right click on user and enable star button) is on top of the list- improved group usability- Offline users can be removed from list (right click on an offline user in list and then remove)- Clear all files shared (option)- Load minimized at startup (option) Hostnameåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç³»ç»Ÿä¿¡æ¯ï¼›host nameThe hostname command not only displays the systemâ€™s host name, but lets them set it as well.12$ hostnamehimanshu-desktop Idåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç³»ç»Ÿä¿¡æ¯ï¼›ç”¨æˆ·ä¿¡æ¯The id command prints user and group information for the current user or specified username.12$ id himanshuuid=1000(himanshu) gid=1000(himanshu) groups=1000(himanshu),4(adm),24(cdrom),27(sudo),30(dip),46(plugdev),108(lpadmin),124(sambashare) Killåˆ†ç±»ï¼šè¿›ç¨‹ç®¡ç†ï¼›The kill command, as the name suggests, helps user kill a process by sending the TERM signal to it.1$ kill [process-id] Killallåˆ†ç±»ï¼šè¿›ç¨‹ç®¡ç†ï¼›The killall command lets you kill a process by name. Unlike kill - which requires ID of the process to be killed - killall just requires the name of the process.1$ killall nautilus Laståˆ†ç±»ï¼šå®‰å…¨ç®¡ç†ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹æœ€è¿‘ç™»å½•ç”¨æˆ·The last command shows listing of last logged in users.1234567$ lasthimanshu pts/11 :0 Thu Mar 2 09:46 still logged inhimanshu pts/1 :0 Thu Mar 2 09:46 still logged inhimanshu :0 :0 Thu Mar 2 09:42 still logged inreboot system boot 4.4.0-62-generic Thu Mar 2 09:41 - 10:36 (00:54)himanshu pts/14 :0 Wed Mar 1 15:17 - 15:52 (00:35)himanshu pts/13 :0 Wed Mar 1 14:40 - down (08:06) Lddåˆ†ç±»ï¼šè½¯ä»¶åŒ…ç®¡ç†ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹ä¸€ä¸ªå…±äº«åº“çš„ä¾èµ–The ldd command displays in output dependencies of a shared library.1234$ ldd /lib/i386-linux-gnu/libcrypt-2.19.solinux-gate.so.1 => (0xb77df000)libc.so.6 => /lib/i386-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0xb75da000)/lib/ld-linux.so.2 (0x80088000) Lnåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›é“¾æŽ¥The ln command is used for creating link between files. For example, the following command would create a link named â€˜lnkâ€™ to a file with name â€˜test.txtâ€™:1$ ln test.txt lnk Locateåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æœç´¢The locate command helps user find a file by name.1$ locate [file-name] Lognameåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç™»å½•ä¿¡æ¯ï¼›The logname command prints the user-name of the current user.12$ lognamehimanshu Lsåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹æ–‡ä»¶åˆ—è¡¨The ls command lists contents of a directory in output.1234$ ls progresscapture.png hlist.o progress progress.h sizes.chlist.c LICENSE progress.1 progress.o sizes.hhlist.h Makefile progress.c README.md sizes.o Lshwåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç³»ç»Ÿä¿¡æ¯ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹ç¡¬ä»¶ä¿¡æ¯The lshw command extracts and displays detailed information on the hardware configuration of the machine.12345678910111213$ sudo lshw[sudo] password for himanshu:himanshu-desktopdescription: Desktop Computerproduct: To Be Filled By O.E.M. (To Be Filled By O.E.M.)vendor: To Be Filled By O.E.M.version: To Be Filled By O.E.M.serial: To Be Filled By O.E.M.width: 32 bitscapabilities: smbios-2.6 dmi-2.6 smp-1.4 smp........ Lscpuåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç³»ç»Ÿä¿¡æ¯ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹ç¡¬ä»¶ä¿¡æ¯-CPU The lscpu command displays in output systemâ€™s CPU architecture information (such as number of CPUs, threads, cores, sockets, and more).12345678910111213141516171819$ lscpuArchitecture: i686CPU op-mode(s): 32-bit, 64-bitByte Order: Little EndianCPU(s): 1On-line CPU(s) list: 0Thread(s) per core: 1Core(s) per socket: 1Socket(s): 1Vendor ID: AuthenticAMDCPU family: 16Model: 6Stepping: 3CPU MHz: 2800.234BogoMIPS: 5600.46Virtualization: AMD-VL1d cache: 64KL1i cache: 64KL2 cache: 1024K Manåˆ†ç±»ï¼šå¸®åŠ©ï¼›man lets you access reference manual for commands, programs/utilities, as well as functions.1$ man ls Md5sumåˆ†ç±»ï¼šè®¡ç®—å™¨ï¼›md5The md5sum command lets you print or check MD5 (128-bit) checksums.12$ md5sum test.txtac34b1f34803a6691ff8b732bb97fbba test.txt Mkdiråˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›åˆ›å»ºç›®å½•The mkdir command lets you create directories.1$ mkdir [dir-name] Mkfifoåˆ†ç±»ï¼šè¿›ç¨‹ç®¡ç†The mkfifo command is used to create named pipes.1$ mkfifo [pipe-name] Moreåˆ†ç±»ï¼šäº¤äº’more is basically a filter for paging through text one screenful at a time.1$ cat [large-file] | more Mvåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›ç§»åŠ¨The mv command lets you either move a file from one directory to another, or rename it.1$ mv test.txt /home/himanshu/Desktop/ Niceåˆ†ç±»ï¼šè¿›ç¨‹ç®¡ç†ï¼›æŒ‡å®šè¿›ç¨‹ä¼˜å…ˆçº§The nice command lets you run a program with modified scheduling priority.123$ nice -n[niceness-value] [program]$ nice -n15 vim Nlåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›è¾“å‡ºè¡Œå·The nl command writes contents of a file to output, and prepends each line with line number.1234$ nl file11 Hi2 How are you3 Bye Nmåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The nm command is used to display symbols from object files. 12345678910111213141516171819$ nm test0804a020 B __bss_start0804841d T compare0804a020 b completed.65910804a018 D __data_start0804a018 W data_start08048360 t deregister_tm_clones080483d0 t __do_global_dtors_aux08049f0c t __do_global_dtors_aux_fini_array_entry0804a01c D __dso_handle08049f14 d _DYNAMIC0804a020 D _edata0804a024 B _end080484e4 T _fini080484f8 R _fp_hw080483f0 t frame_dummy......... Nprocåˆ†ç±»ï¼šè¿›ç¨‹ç®¡ç†The nproc command displays the number of processing units available to the current process.12$ nproc1 Odåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The od command lets you dump files in octal as well as some other formats.12345678910$ od /bin/ls0000000 042577 043114 000401 000001 000000 000000 000000 0000000000020 000002 000003 000001 000000 140101 004004 000064 0000000000040 122104 000001 000000 000000 000064 000040 000011 0000500000060 000034 000033 000006 000000 000064 000000 100064 0040040000100 100064 004004 000440 000000 000440 000000 000005 0000000000120 000004 000000 000003 000000 000524 000000 100524 004004......... Passwdåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç”¨æˆ·æƒé™ç®¡ç†The passwd command is used for changing passwords for user accounts.123$ passwd himanshuChanging password for himanshu.(current) UNIX password: Pasteåˆ†ç±»ï¼šäº¤äº’The paste command lets you merge lines of files. For example, if â€˜file1â€™ contains the following lines:123456789101112131415$ cat file1HiMy name isHimanshuAroraIAmaLinux researcherand tutorialwriterThen the following 'paste' command will join all the lines of the file:$ paste -s file1Hi My name is Himanshu Arora I Am a Linux researcher and tutorial writer Pidofåˆ†ç±»ï¼šè¿›ç¨‹ç®¡ç†The pidof command gives you the process ID of a running program/process.12$ pidof nautilus2714 Pingåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç½‘ç»œç®¡ç†The ping command is used to check whether or not a system is up and responding. It sends ICMP ECHO_REQUEST to network hosts.12345$ ping howtoforge.comPING howtoforge.com (104.24.0.68) 56(84) bytes of data.64 bytes from 104.24.0.68: icmp_seq=1 ttl=58 time=47.3 ms64 bytes from 104.24.0.68: icmp_seq=2 ttl=58 time=51.9 ms64 bytes from 104.24.0.68: icmp_seq=3 ttl=58 time=57.4 ms Psåˆ†ç±»ï¼šè¿›ç¨‹ç®¡ç†The ps command displays information (in the form of a snapshot) about the currently active processes.1234$ psPID TTY TIME CMD4537 pts/1 00:00:00 bash20592 pts/1 00:00:00 ps Pstreeåˆ†ç±»ï¼šè¿›ç¨‹ç®¡ç†The pstree command produces information about running processes in the form of a tree.12345678$ pstreeinit???ModemManager???2*[{ModemManager}]??NetworkManager???dhclient? ??dnsmasq? ??3*[{NetworkManager}]??accounts-daemon???2*[{accounts-daemon}]??acpid??atop PwdThe pwd command displays the name of current/working directory.12$ pwd/home/himanshu Rmåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The rm command lets you remove files and/or directories.1$ rm [file-name] Rmdiråˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The rmdir command allows you delete empty directories.1$ rmdir [dir-name] Scpåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The scp command lets you securely copy files between systems on a network.1$ scp [name-and-path-of-file-to-transfer] [user]@[host]:[dest-path] Sdiffåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›æ–‡æœ¬æ¯”å¯¹ side-by-sideThe sdiff command lets you perform a side-by-side merge of differences between two files.1$ sdiff file1 file2 Sedåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†;ç¼–ç¨‹å·¥å…·sed is basically a stream editor that allows users to perform basic text transformations on an input stream (a file or input from a pipeline).12$ echo "Welcome to Howtoforge" | sed -e 's/Howtoforge/HowtoForge/g'Welcome to HowtoForge Seqåˆ†ç±»ï¼šè®¡ç®—å™¨The seq commands prints numbers from FIRST to LAST, in steps of INCREMENT. For example, if FIRST is 1, LAST is 10, and INCREMENT is 2, then hereâ€™s the output this command produces: 123456$ seq 1 2 1013579 Sha1sumåˆ†ç±»ï¼šè®¡ç®—å™¨The sha1sum command is used to print or check SHA1 (160-bit) checksums.12$ sha1sum test.txt955e48dfc9256866b3e5138fcea5ea0406105e68 test.txt ShutdownThe shutdown command lets user shut the system in a safe way.1$ shutdown Sizeåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The size command lists the section sizes as well as the total size for an object or archive file.123$ size testtext data bss dec hex filename1204 280 4 1488 5d0 test SleepThe sleep command lets user specify delay for a specified amount of time. You can use it to delay an operation like:1$ sleep 10; shutdown Sortåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The sort command lets you sort lines of text files. For example, if â€˜file2â€™ contains the following names:123456789101112$ cat file2zeuskyansamadamThen running the sort command produces the following output:$ sort file2adamkyansamzeus Splitåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The split command, as the name suggests, splits a file into fixed-size pieces. By default, files with name like xaa, xab, and xac are produced. $ split [file-name] Sshssh is basically OpenSSH SSH client. It provides secure encrypted communication between two untrusted hosts over an insecure network.1$ ssh [user-name]@[remote-server] Statåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The stat command displays status related to a file or a file-system.123456789$ stat test.txtFile: â€˜test.txtâ€™Size: 20 Blocks: 8 IO Block: 4096 regular fileDevice: 801h/2049d Inode: 284762 Links: 2Access: (0664/-rw-rw-r--) Uid: ( 0/ root) Gid: ( 0/ root)Access: 2017-03-03 12:41:27.791206947 +0530Modify: 2017-02-28 16:05:15.952472926 +0530Change: 2017-03-02 11:10:00.028548636 +0530Birth: - Stringsåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The strings command displays in output printable character sequences that are at least 4 characters long. For example, when a binary executable â€˜testâ€™ was passed as an argument to this command, following output was produced:1234567891011121314151617$ strings test/lib/ld-linux.so.2libc.so.6_IO_stdin_usedputs__libc_start_main__gmon_start__GLIBC_2.0PTRhQVhI[^_]EQUAL;*2$"GCC: (Ubuntu 4.8.4-2ubuntu1~14.04.3) 4.8.4............ Suåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç”¨æˆ·æƒé™ç®¡ç†The su command lets you change user-identity. Mostly, this command is used to become root or superuser.1$ su [user-name] Sudoåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç”¨æˆ·æƒé™ç®¡ç†The sudo command lets a permitted user run a command as another user (usually root or superuser).1$ sudo [command] Sumåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The sum command prints checksum and block counts for each input file.12$ sum readme.txt45252 5 Tacåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The tac command prints input files in reverse. Functionality-wise, it does the reverse of what the cat command does.12345678910$ cat file2zeuskyansamadam$ tac file2adamsamkyanzeus Tailåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The tail command displays in output the last 10 lines of a file.1$ tail [file-name] Talkåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç½‘ç»œç®¡ç†The talk command lets users talk with each other.1$ talk [user-name] Taråˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›åŽ‹ç¼©&è§£åŽ‹ç¼©tar is an archiving utility that lets you create as well as extract archive files. For example, to create archive.tar from files â€˜fooâ€™ and â€˜barâ€™, use the following command:123$ tar -cf archive.tar foo barMore... Teeåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The tee command reads from standard input and write to standard output as well as files.1234$ uname | tee file2Linux$ cat file2Linux Teståˆ†ç±»ï¼šè®¡ç®—å™¨The test command checks file types and compare values. For example, you can use it in the following way:12$ test 7 -gt 5 && echo "true"true Timeåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ€§èƒ½ç›‘æµ‹The time command is used to summarize system resource usage of a program. For example:12345678910$ time ping google.comPING google.com (216.58.220.206) 56(84) bytes of data.64 bytes from del01s08-in-f14.1e100.net (216.58.220.206): icmp_seq=1 ttl=52 time=44.2 ms^C--- google.com ping statistics ---1 packets transmitted, 1 received, 0% packet loss, time 0msrtt min/avg/max/mdev = 44.288/44.288/44.288/0.000 msreal 0m0.676suser 0m0.000ssys 0m0.000s Topåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç³»ç»Ÿä¿¡æ¯ï¼›æ€§èƒ½ç›‘æµ‹ï¼›æ€§èƒ½æ¦‚è§ˆã€‚è¯¦ç»†ä»‹ç» >>>more>>>The top command gives a dynamic real-time view of a running system (in terms of its processes). For example:1$ top Linux æ€§èƒ½è¯Šæ–­:è´Ÿè½½è¯„ä¼° Linux æ€§èƒ½è¯Šæ–­:å¿«é€Ÿæ£€æŸ¥å•(Netflixç‰ˆ) æ“ä½œç³»ç»ŸåŽŸç† | How Linux Worksï¼ˆä¸‰ï¼‰ï¼šMemory Touchåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The touch command lets you change file timestamps (the access and modification times). When name of a non-existent file is passed as an argument, that file gets created.1$ touch [file-name] Tråˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†The tr command can be used to translate/squeeze/delete characters. For example, hereâ€™s how you can use it to convert lowercase characters to uppercase:12$ echo 'howtoforge' | tr "[:lower:]" "[:upper:]"HOWTOFORGE Ttyåˆ†ç±»ï¼šèµ„æºç®¡ç†The tty command prints the filename of the terminal connected to standard input.12$ tty/dev/pts/10 Unameåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç”¨æˆ·æƒé™ç®¡ç†The uname command prints certain system information.12$ uname -aLinux himanshu-desktop 4.4.0-62-generic #83~14.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Wed Jan 18 18:10:26 UTC 2017 i686 athlon i686 GNU/Linux Uniqåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›å¾…è¡¥å……ä¿¡æ¯The Uniq command is used to report or omit repeated lines. For example, if â€˜file2â€™ contains the following data:1234567891011$ cat file2Welcome to HowtoForgeWelcome to HowtoForgeA Linux tutorial websiteThanksThen you can use the uniq command to omit the repeated line.$ uniq file2Welcome to HowtoForgeA Linux tutorial websiteThanks Unexpandåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›å¾…è¡¥å……ä¿¡æ¯The unexpand command converts spaces present in the input file(s) into tabs, and writes the file contents to standard output.1$ unexpand file1 Uptimeåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç³»ç»Ÿä¿¡æ¯ï¼›æ€§èƒ½ç›‘æµ‹ï¼›æŸ¥çœ‹è´Ÿè½½ã€‚è¯¦ç»†ä»‹ç» >>>more>>>The uptime command tells how long the system has been running.12$ uptime15:59:59 up 6:20, 4 users, load average: 0.81, 0.92, 0.82 Usersåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç”¨æˆ·æƒé™ç®¡ç†ï¼›å¾…è¡¥å……ä¿¡æ¯The users command displays in output the usernames of users currently logged in to the current host.12$ usershimanshu himanshu himanshu himanshu Vdiråˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›å¾…è¡¥å……ä¿¡æ¯The vdir command lists information about contents of a directory (current directory by default).12345$ vdirtotal 1088-rw-rw-r-- 1 himanshu himanshu 4850 May 20 2015 test_backup.pdf-rw-rw-r-- 1 himanshu himanshu 2082 May 28 2015 test-filled.pdf-rw-rw-r-- 1 himanshu himanshu 7101 May 28 2015 test.pdf Vimåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç¼–è¾‘å™¨vim is basically a text/programming editor. The name â€˜vimâ€™ stands for Vi IMproved as the editor is upwards compatible to the Vi editor.1$ vim [file-name] Wåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ€§èƒ½ç›‘æµ‹The w command displays information about the users currently on the machine, and their processes.1234567$ w16:18:07 up 6:39, 4 users, load average: 0.07, 0.32, 0.53USER TTY FROM LOGIN@ IDLE JCPU PCPU WHAThimanshu :0 :0 09:39 ?xdm? 1:08m 0.25s init --userhimanshu pts/0 :0 09:41 6:36m 0.84s 7.84s gnome-terminalhimanshu pts/10 :0 14:51 0.00s 0.16s 0.00s whimanshu pts/11 :0 15:41 35:19 0.05s 0.05s bash Wallåˆ†ç±»ï¼šé€šè®¯ï¼›å¾…è¡¥å……ä¿¡æ¯The wall command lets you write and send a message to other users that are currently logged in.1$ wall [your-message] Watchåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ€§èƒ½ç›‘æµ‹The watch command can be used to monitor a programâ€™s output. It runs the program repeatedly, displaying its output and errors. For example:1$ watch date Wcåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›å¾…è¡¥å……ä¿¡æ¯The wc command prints newline, word, and byte counts for a file.12$ wc test.txt0 3 20 test.txt Whatisåˆ†ç±»ï¼šå¸®åŠ©The whatis command displays single-line manual page descriptions.1234$ whatis mkdirmkdir (1) - make directoriesmkdir (2) - create a directorymkdir (1posix) - make directories Whichåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›ä»¥æ¥The which command basically lets you locate a command - the file and the path of the file that gets executed. For example:12$ which date/bin/date Whoåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç™»å½•ä¿¡æ¯The who command shows who is logged on.12345$ whohimanshu :0 2017-03-03 09:39 (:0)himanshu pts/0 2017-03-03 09:41 (:0)himanshu pts/10 2017-03-03 14:51 (:0)himanshu pts/11 2017-03-03 15:41 (:0) Whereisåˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ï¼›ä»¥æ¥The whereis command shows in output locations of the binary, source, and manual page files for a command.12$ whereis lsls: /bin/ls /usr/share/man/man1/ls.1posix.gz /usr/share/man/man1/ls.1.gz Whoamiåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç™»å½•ä¿¡æ¯The whoami command prints effective userid of the current user.12$ whoamihimanshu Xargsåˆ†ç±»ï¼šç¼–ç¨‹å·¥å…·The xargs command builds and executes command lines from standard input. In laymanâ€™s terms, it reads items from stdin and executes a command passed to it as an argument. For example, hereâ€™s how you can use xargs to find the word â€œLinuxâ€ in the files whose names are passed to it as input.12345678$ xargs grep "Linux"file1file2file3file1:Linux researcherfile2:A Linux tutorial websitefile3:Linux is opensourceMore... ´äº†èˆžå°ä¸Šçš„ç¥¨æˆ¿çºªå½•ã€‚åœ¨éŸ³ä¹å‰§ä¸­ï¼Œé›¨æžœçš„è‹±é›„åœ¨åŸè¯µï¼šä¸€é¦–ç”µè§†é€‰ç§€èŠ‚ç›®é€‰æ‰‹å–œçˆ±çš„â€”â€”â€œå¸¦ä»–å›žå®¶â€ã€‚Belloså…ˆç”Ÿçš„å·¥ä½œæ¯‹å®è¯´ï¼Œä»–å°†â€œæ‚²æƒ¨ä¸–ç•Œâ€ä»Žåˆ¶é€ è€…å’Œä»–çš„æ—¶ä»£å®Œæ•´é‡çŽ°ã€‚ Economist:By the book How Victor Hugo came to write â€œLes MisÃ©rablesâ€, his magnum opus The extraordinary story of a book that changed the world The Novel of the Century: The Extraordinary Adventure of Les MisÃ©rables. By David Bellos. Particular Books; 307 pages; Â£20. To be published in America by Farrar, Straus & Giroux in March; $27. â€œAS LONG as there are ignorance and poverty on Earth,â€ wrote Victor Hugo in his preface to â€œLes MisÃ©rablesâ€, â€œbooks such as this one may not be useless.â€ Over the 155 years since it was first published in France and then elsewhere, the novel has never lost its relevanceâ€”or its popularity. Around 65 film versions (the first in 1909) make â€œLes MisÃ©rablesâ€ the most frequently adapted novel of all time. The first stage musical opened in Philadelphia in January 1863. Since 1980 Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel SchÃ¶nbergâ€™s operatic melodrama has been performed more than 53,000 times in 44 countries and 349 cities. Yet, from the outset, adapters and translators cherry-picked elements from their supersized source. British admirers had to wait until 2008 for a complete English text of the novel in the order in which the author had planned it to be read. Even to lovers of â€œLes Misâ€, Hugoâ€™s world-shaking blockbuster can feel like a lost continent. David Bellos, an English-born professor of French literature at Princeton University and an eminent translator, navigates through its five parts, 48 â€œbooksâ€ and 365 chapters with clarity and wit. At once erudite and entertaining, he shows how the novelâ€™s magic lies in its multitasking versatility. Hugoâ€™s extraordinary feat is to deliver â€œan intricately realistic portraitâ€ of France after Napoleon, â€œa dramatic page-turnerâ€ packed with suspenseâ€”and a demonstration of â€œgenerous moral principlesâ€ that readers still find appealing today. Hugo, already the author of â€œNotre-Dame de Parisâ€ and a literary superstar as a poet, playwright and novelist, began in 1845 to write his story of a former convict seeking a new life in a society rigged against the poor and outcast. Around the questing figure of Jean Valjean, freed from the prison-hulks in 1815 to make his way against the steepest odds, Hugo stitched a vast but â€œvery tightly knitâ€ tapestry of social strife and personal rebirth. The revolution of 1848, in which the radical firebrand discovered that â€œhis head was with orderâ€ although his heart â€œwas with the poorâ€, interrupted Hugoâ€™s mammoth project. It resumed after the exiled writer, banished by the upstart emperor, Napoleon III, settled on the Channel Island of Guernsey: no longer a â€œbrilliant careeristâ€ but a â€œstand-alone protesterâ€. Curiously, this â€œtiny feudal outpost of the British crownâ€ hosted the gestation and birth of a book that won hearts and changed minds across the world. The editing and printing of the precious manuscript depended on the schedules of Queen Victoriaâ€™s Royal Mail and the Guernsey steamer timetables. In 1861 â€œthe biggest deal in book historyâ€ saw Hugo paid the equivalent of 20 years of a bishopâ€™s stipend: enough â€œto build a small railwayâ€. By late 1862, the year of publication, Charles Wilbourâ€™s English translation was reported to be â€œthe largest order ever placed for a book in Americaâ€. Save for Hugoâ€™s literary rivals (Alexandre Dumas likened it to â€œwading through mudâ€), everybody loved the long haul of Valjeanâ€™s rehabilitation in the company of characters who soon entered folklore: the street-girl Fantine, her daughter Cosette, the urchin Gavroche, the student Marius. Shorn of its condemnation of slavery, the novel even circulated in a pirate edition among Confederate soldiers during the American civil war. In a weary pun on their commanderâ€™s name, they dubbed themselves â€œLeeâ€™s Miserablesâ€. From the humane treatment of ex-offenders to the care of street children, â€œLes MisÃ©rablesâ€ spearheaded calls for reform and contributed to â€œthe future improvement of societyâ€. Few books really change the world. This one did, long before it broke box-office records on stage. In the musical Hugoâ€™s hero intonesâ€”in a song loved by television talent-show contestantsâ€”â€œBring Him Homeâ€. Mr Bellos does just that, as he restores â€œLes Misâ€ to its maker and his times. This article appeared in the Books and arts section of the print edition under the headline â€œBy the bookâ€ æ‰©å±•é˜…è¯» å¤å…¸éŸ³ä¹ä½Žä¿—å² èˆžå°å‰§ï¼šå—æµ·åä¸‰éƒŽ ç”µå½±è¯„è®º|çµé­‚è§£ç ã€Šæž—è‚¯ã€‹ ç”µå½±è¯„è®º|æ–¯çš®å°”ä¼¯æ ¼çš„æž—è‚¯æƒ…æ€€ é£Žæœˆé›†|è¯—ä¸‰ç™¾ï¼Œæ€æ— é‚ª ä¸–çºªå°è¯´ã€Šæ‚²æƒ¨ä¸–ç•Œã€‹ çº¢æ¥¼æ•…äº‹ï¼šä½©åˆ€æ²½é…’ä½œé•¿æ­Œ çº¢æ¥¼æ•…äº‹ï¼šåº·ç†™çš„ç§˜å¯†æƒ…æŠ¥ç³»ç»Ÿ æ±Ÿå—å›­æž—é‰´èµ|å—äº¬çž»å›­ æ‘„å½±ä¸“è¾‘|ç æµ·èˆªç©ºèˆªå¤©å±•è§ˆ å‚è€ƒæ–‡çŒ®1ã€ Youtube :Bring Him Home 2ã€ Amazon: The Novel of the Century: The Extraordinary Adventure of Les MisÃ©rables3ã€Wiki David Bellos

¼ç®¡åˆ¶çš„ã€‚åªæœ‰å…«å®¶å›½è¥çš„è¿›å£å•†åŠå…¶é™„å±žå…¬å¸èŽ·å‡†å°†å¤–å›½ä¹¦ç›®å¼•å…¥å†…åœ°ã€‚æ¶ˆè´¹è€…ä»¬æ¸´æœ›çš„ç¦ä¹¦åœ¨ä»–ä»¬å‘å¾€å·²ä¹…çš„å°æ¹¾å’Œé¦™æ¸¯ï¼Œé‚£é‡Œå¯ä»¥äº«å—å¤§é™†è¯»è€…æ— å°½ç®¡å›¾ä¹¦é”€å”®çš„æ€»é‡åœ¨ä¸‹é™ï¼Œä¸­å›½çš„ç½‘ä¸Šå›¾ä¹¦é”€å”®åœ¨è¿‡åŽ»äº”å¹´ä¸­çš„å¢žé•¿è¶…è¿‡å››å€ã€‚éšç€ç”Ÿæ´»æ°´å¹³çš„æé«˜ï¼Œå„¿ç«¥æ–‡å­¦ä½œå“çš„é”€é‡å¢žé•¿å°¤å…¶è¿…çŒ›ã€‚ China tries to restrict access to foreign childrenâ€™s booksLike millions of young readers around the world, Chinese children have grown up with popular titles such as Roald Dahlâ€™s Fantastic Mr Fox and the Harry Potter series.But Beijing is now introducing new measures to restrict access to foreign books and publications as it opens a new front in its battle to limit outside influence on Chinese society.Regulators have given verbal instructions to publishers to limit the number of childrenâ€™s books written by foreign authors made available in China, according to three people with knowledge of the order. The decision would reduce the thousands of childrenâ€™s titles published in Chinese translation every year to just a few hundred, one of them said.Taobao, one of Chinaâ€™s biggest ecommerce sites and owned by Jack Maâ€™s Alibaba, said on Friday it would prohibit the sale of all foreign publications on its platform.â€œIn order to regulate the Taobao online shopping platform and to create a safe and secure online shopping environment to enhance consumer confidence and satisfaction, Taobao will add all foreign publications and buyer information to its embargo rules,â€ Alibaba said in a statement. Industry experts expressed surprise at the ruling and questioned how it would affect a fast-growing market. â€œI canâ€™t imagine this restriction to be possible, because its implementation is so difficult, and it also has no benefit whatsoever for the people or the country,â€ said a senior Chinese books editor, who asked not to be identified.Jo Lusby, managing director for Penguin Random House North Asia, said: â€œThe childrenâ€™s market is substantial and growing in China, in particular in the pre-school and picture book area.â€On Amazonâ€™s Chinese site, six out of the top 10 bestselling childrenâ€™s books were by foreign authors, including Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, the seventh and final part of JK Rowlingâ€™s series about the adventures of a boy-wizard, and Sam McBratneyâ€™s illustration Guess How Much I Love You, which has sold 28m copies worldwide since being published 20 years ago. #THE CHILDRENâ€™S MARKET IS SUBSTANTIAL AND GROWING IN CHINA, IN PARTICULAR IN THE PRE-SCHOOL AND PICTURE BOOK AREA It is not known which part of the Chinese government is leading the drive to limit the supply of childrenâ€™s books. It was also unclear whether the ruling was having an effect, as internet searches on Friday revealed hundreds of Chinese vendors selling foreign childrenâ€™s books.Ambiguity in the wording of Alibabaâ€™s notice would also allow it to ban the sale of foreign video games, CDs and DVDs. One Taobao vendor wrote to customers: â€œAll we can say is, everyone treasure what you have! From now on, we can be confident in saying that it will be more difficult, more expensive and more rare to buy foreign goods.â€The contents of Chinese bookshelves and magazine stands are strictly regulated. Only eight state-owned importers and their subsidiaries are licensed to bring foreign titles into the mainland.Consumers eager for banned books have long sought them out in Taiwan and Hong Kong, which enjoy unfettered access to volumes inaccessible to mainland readers.However, online vendors have offered a loophole, with cleverly worded searches turning up thousands of illicit titles sold by so-called daigou, enterprising intermediaries who buy goods from abroad and sell them on to mainland customers.Online book sales in China have more than quadrupled during the past five years, even as overall book sales have dipped. Sales of childrenâ€™s literature in particular have soared as living standards have risen. æ‰©å±•é˜…è¯» æ•°æ®å¯è§†åŒ–ï¼ˆåï¼‰å…¬å…±æ•°æ®æºåˆ—è¡¨

Sasha Goldshtein: Making .NET applications faster Sasha Goldshtein:Tracing Runtime Events in .NET Core on Linux ç« äº¦æ˜¥|agentzh Nginx developer, DTrace åŠ¨æ€è¿½è¸ªæŠ€æœ¯æ¼«è°ˆ Gustavo Duarte OS kernel Julia Evans OS kernel,DTrace,Rust Front Specialisté‚±ä¿Šæ¶› Front, Tools, methodology ä¸»è¦çš„ç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€æ˜¯Javaå’ŒJavaScriptï¼Œä¹Ÿæœ‰å‡ å¹´Linuxä¸‹Cè¯­è¨€çš„å¼€å‘ç»éªŒï¼Œå–œæ¬¢å„ç§åŠ¨æ€è¯­è¨€ï¼Œå°¤å…¶å¦‚JavaScriptï¼Œè€ŒçŽ°åœ¨Rubyä¹Ÿæˆäº†æˆ‘å·¥å…·ç®±é‡Œæœ€ä¸»è¦çš„å·¥å…·äº†ã€‚ç›®å‰å…³æ³¨åœ¨å‰ç«¯ï¼Œå¯¹äºŽ ä½¿ç”¨å‰ç«¯æŠ€æœ¯æ­å»ºè½»é‡çº§çš„Webåº”ç”¨å°¤ä¸ºæ„Ÿå…´è¶£ã€‚ ã€ŠJavaScriptæ ¸å¿ƒæ¦‚å¿µåŠå®žè·µã€‹ã€Šè½»é‡çº§Webåº”ç”¨å¼€å‘ã€‹ã€Š3å‘¨3Webè®¾è®¡ã€‹ã€ŠFun with underscore.jsã€‹ é˜®ä¸€å³° My name is Ruan YiFeng(é˜®ä¸€å³°). You can call me Frank. I was born in 1970s.I am an IT developer focusing on web technology, and a strong advocate and believer of Free Software.Now I am employed by Alipay.com as an Node/JavaScript engineer.I have an Economics degree, and once worked for a local college in Shanghai as an assistant professor. entry.content: æ‘˜è¦ The Economist:Books of the Year 2017 The Economist:Books of the Year 2016 Books of the Year 2016ã€Šç»æµŽå­¦äººã€‹æ¯å¹´éƒ½ä¼šæŽ¨å‡ºä¸€ä¸ªå¹´åº¦ä¹¦å•ï¼ŒåŒ…å«æ—¶äº‹æ”¿æ²»ã€ä¼ è®°&å›žå¿†å½•ã€åŽ†å²ã€ç»æµŽ&å•†ä¸šã€æ–‡åŒ–&ç¤¾ä¼šã€å°è¯´ã€ç§‘å­¦&æŠ€æœ¯ç­‰æ¿å—ã€‚2016å¹´åº¦çš„ä¹¦å•é‡Œé¢ï¼Œå’Œä¸­å›½å¯†åˆ‡ç›¸å…³æœ‰5æœ¬ï¼š The Water Kingdom: A Secret History of ChinaBy Philip Ball. Bodley Head; 316 pages; Â£25. To be published in America by University of Chicago Press in March 2017 How two great riversâ€”the Yellow river and the Yangziâ€”shaped Chinaâ€™s history. By a British science writer who for 20 years was an editor at Nature. Chinaâ€™s FutureBy David Shambaugh. Polity; 195 pages; $19.95 and Â£14.99No country has modernised its economy without also becoming a democracy. A respected American political scientist asks whether China can break the mould. CEO, China: The Rise of Xi XXXBy Kerry Brown. I.B. Tauris; 288 pages; $28 and Â£20What sort of leader is Xi XXX? There are few political questions to which the answer will have greater bearing on people as this. By an expert British China-watcher. Chinaâ€™s Crony Capitalism: The Dynamics of Regime DecayBy Minxin Pei. Harvard University Press; 365 pages; $35 and Â£25.95How decentralising the rights of control over state property, without clarifying the rules of ownership, offered those who rule China the greatest chance in history to grow rich, by a professor of government now based in California. Alibaba: The House That Jack Ma BuiltBy Duncan Clark. Ecco; 287 pages; $27.99 and Â£18.99An intriguing insiderâ€™s account of how Jack Ma conquered Chinaâ€™s internet, by an early adviser to the company 1----------------------------------------- The best books of 2016 are about China, language, microbes, hereditary power,inequality and medieval manuscripts Dec 10th 2016 Timekeeper Politics and current affairsChinaâ€™s FutureBy David Shambaugh. Polity; 195 pages; $19.95 and Â£14.99No country has modernised its economy without also becoming a democracy. A respected American political scientist asks whether China can break the mould. Black Wind, White Snow: The Rise of Russiaâ€™s New NationalismBy Charles Clover. Yale University Press; 360 pages; $35 and Â£25A veteran Financial Times correspondent analyses what really motivates the regime in Moscow by tracing the rise of Eurasianism: the belief (crudely put) that Russiaâ€™s national identity is determined by ethnicity, geography and destiny. The Euro and the Battle of IdeasBy Markus Brunnermeier, Harold James and Jean-Pierre Landau. Princeton University Press; 440 pages; $35 and Â£24.95Three authors focus on France and Germany to tease out the clashing economic ideas that make up the euro project. The Germans like rules and discipline, and fret about excessive debt and the moral hazard created by bail-outs. The French prefer flexibility and discretion, and worry about the lack of a mutualised debt instrument. German policymakers are often lawyers, French ones more frequently economists. Not a happy marriage. CEO, China: The Rise of Xi JinpingBy Kerry Brown. I.B. Tauris; 288 pages; $28 and Â£20What sort of leader is Xi Jinping? There are few political questions to which the answer will have greater bearing on people as this. By an expert British China-watcher. Chinaâ€™s Crony Capitalism: The Dynamics of Regime DecayBy Minxin Pei. Harvard University Press; 365 pages; $35 and Â£25.95How decentralising the rights of control over state property, without clarifying the rules of ownership, offered those who rule China the greatest chance in history to grow rich, by a professor of government now based in California. The Egyptians: A Radical Story By Jack Shenker. Allen Lane; 528 pages; Â£15.99A refreshing account, by a young reporter on the Guardian, of the movement that overthrew Hosni Mubarak in 2011. What distinguishes his writing from othersâ€™ is his presence in the slums, factories and homes where Egyptians first began questioning their relations with their rulers. Mr Shenker evokes despair at the economy of this badly run country, but also surprising hope for its future, thanks to a young generation that says it is â€œno longer prepared to put up with the old crapâ€. Trials: On Death Row in PakistanBy Isabel Buchanan. Jonathan Cape; 264 pages; Â£16.99Two young lawyers, one Pakistani and one British (the author), launch themselves into the dark world of Pakistanâ€™s death row, where 8,000 people await execution. A remarkable first book written with verve and an eye for telling detail. Hillbilly Elegy: A Memoir of a Family and Culture in CrisisBy J.D. Vance. Harper; 264 pages; $27.99. William Collins; Â£14.99Why so many people want to believe that Donald Trump will bring back manufacturing jobs and keep immigrants out. Possibly the most important recent book about America. The Art of Charlie Chan Hock ChyeBy Sonny Liew. Pantheon; 320 pages; $30 and Â£25A brilliantly inventive graphic novel, which took several years to complete, weighs up the costs and benefits of life in the small, authoritarian, model city-state that Lee Kwan Yu founded half a century ago. By a Malaysian-born comic artist and illustrator, now based in Singapore. The Way to the Spring: Life and Death in PalestineBy Ben Ehrenreich. Penguin Press; 428 pages; $28. Granta; Â£14.99An elegant and moving account of the trials of one family, a tale that is symbolic of the daily lives of many Palestinians. Biography and memoirThe Return: Fathers, Sons and the Land In BetweenBy Hisham Matar. Random House; 256 pages; $26. Viking; Â£14.99A beautifully written memoir that deals with the nature of family, the emotions of exile and the ties that link the present with the pastâ€”in particular, the son with his father, Jaballa Matar, who disappeared in a notorious Libyan prison. Elizabeth: The Forgotten YearsBy John Guy. Viking; 490 pages; $35 and Â£25Most historians focus on the early decades, with Elizabethâ€™s last years acting as a postscript to the beheading of Mary Queen of Scots and the defeat of the Spanish Armada. An Australian-born historian, now a fellow at Cambridge, argues that this period is crucial to understanding a more human side of the smart redhead. Half-Lion: How P.V. Narasimha Rao Transformed IndiaBy Vinay Sitapati. Penguin India; 391 pages; 699 rupeesThe real father of Indiaâ€™s economic reforms deserves a place alongside Nehru as Indiaâ€™s most important prime minister. Instead he was cast into ignominy and obscurity. An important book, by a young doctoral student at Princeton, that deserves wider circulation. When Breath Becomes Air By Paul Kalanithi. Random House; 238 pages; $25. Bodley Head; Â£12.99A young neurosurgeon, dying of cancer, examines his life, especially the gift of language, the parts of the brain that control it and its centrality to what makes us human. A powerful and compelling read. Karl Marx: Greatness and Illusion By Gareth Stedman Jones. Belknap; 768 pages; $35. Allen Lane; Â£35A British historian re-evaluates Marx in the 21st century. There is no better guide than this professor of the history of ideas at the University of London. Negroland: A Memoir By Margo Jefferson. Vintage; 248 pages; $16. Granta; Â£12.99Growing up an African-American of privilege and wealth might seem cushy. But this penetrating memoir shows how those who were spared the brutality of southern segregation nevertheless had to learn to navigate a much subtler set of tacit rules and assumptions: excel, but donâ€™t show off; be comfortable anywhere, but be aware that prejudice can rear its ugly head at any moment. Kenneth Clark: Life, Art and â€œCivilisationâ€By James Stourton. Knopf; 478 pages; $35. William Collins; Â£30At once cold and grand, Kenneth Clark would be easy to mock. A carefully researched and thoughtful biography of a conflicted and curiously unknowable man who became the most brilliant cultural populist of the 20th century, by a former chairman of Sothebyâ€™s. Born to Run By Bruce Springsteen. Simon & Schuster; 528 pages; $32.50 and Â£20The timely autobiography of the bard of American deindustrialisation, whose songs recognise and honour blue-collar woes. His stories have never aged; years after they were written they remain a lesson in empathy for the white-collar fans he has always attracted. But You Did Not Come BackBy Marceline Loridan-Ivens. Translated by Sandra Smith. Atlantic Monthly Press; 112 pages; $22. Faber; Â£12.99In 1944, when she was 15, the author and her father were captured and deported; he to Auschwitz, she to Birkenau. She returned; he never did. It took her 70 years to write her story. In tight, unsparing prose, she confronts the delusions her father held, and the lies she told herself. A small book with a big voice. The Civil Wars of Julia Ward Howe A BiographyBy Elaine Showalter. Simon & Schuster; 243 pages; $28A delightful life, by a spirited academic, of a 19th-century American woman who wrote poetry, plays and books, became a tireless speaker for feminist causes, notably womenâ€™s right to vote. Her life intersected with Longfellow, the Brownings, Louisa May Alcott and Henry James. But she is best known for writing the words to â€œThe Battle Hymn of the Republicâ€. Outlandish Knight: The Byzantine Life of Steven RuncimanBy Minoo Dinshaw. Allen Lane; 767 pages; Â£30By the time he died, in 2000 at the age of 97, Sir Steven Runciman had become convinced that he was a relic of a past age and the embodiment of a nearly mythical era. A lively life of a colourful British historian who was best known for his work on the Crusades, by a promising young author. A debut to be proud of. HistoryThe Water Kingdom: A Secret History of ChinaBy Philip Ball. Bodley Head; 316 pages; Â£25. To be published in America by University of Chicago Press in March 2017 How two great riversâ€”the Yellow river and the Yangziâ€”shaped Chinaâ€™s history. By a British science writer who for 20 years was an editor at Nature. The Romanovs: 1613-1918By Simon Sebag Montefiore. Knopf; 784 pages; $35. Weidenfeld & Nicolson; Â£25A cruel history of hereditary power, by a master storyteller who lifts this unfamiliar narrative with vivid, amusing and surprising details. The Pursuit of Power: Europe 1815-1914By Richard Evans. Viking; 928 pages; $40. Allen Lane; Â£35A distinguished scholar of Germany tots up the winners and losers in the century after the Battle of Waterloo, which could rightly be described as the first age of globalisation. Heart of Europe: A History of the Holy Roman EmpireBy Peter Wilson. Belknap; 941 pages; $39.95. Allen Lane; Â£35The Holy Roman Empire, on paper, looked more like a Jackson Pollock painting than a blueprint for modern Europeâ€”and yet it worked well, nonetheless. A masterly retelling, by an Oxford historian. Lenin on the TrainBy Catherine Merridale. Allen Lane; 353 pages; Â£25. To be published in America by Metropolitan in March 2017How Vladimir Leninâ€™s railway journey from Switzerland to Russia led to the revolution and changed his countryâ€”and the worldâ€”for ever. An insightful and sympathetic account, by one of the foremost historians of Russia. East West Street: On the Origins of Genocide and Crimes Against HumanityBy Philippe Sands. Knopf; 448 pages; $32.50 Weidenfeld & Nicolson; Â£20A distinguished Franco-British advocate traces how a single important word entered the legal canon, while examining the lives of those who brought it into being and the wartime experiences of his own Jewish relatives in Europe. An un-put-downable winner of the Baillie Gifford prize for non-fiction. Economics and businessThe Rise and Fall of American Growth: The US Standard of Living since the Civil WarBy Robert Gordon. Princeton University Press; 762 pages; $39.95 and Â£29.95Why economic growth soared in America in the early 20th century, and why it wonâ€™t be soaring again any time soon, by an outspoken economist who teaches at Northwestern University. Global Inequality: A New Approach for the Age of GlobalisationBy Branko Milanovic. Belknap; 299 pages; $29.95. Harvard University Press; Â£23.95Surprisingly little is known about what causes inequality. An economist at the Luxembourg Income Study Centre and the City University of New York proposes a bold and interesting new theory. The Great Convergence: Information Technology and the New GlobalizationBy Richard Baldwin. Belknap; 329 pages; $29.95 and Â£22.95Globalisation has changed fundamentally since the internet revolution in the 1990s. Whereas 20th-century trade involved competition between countries, 21st-century trade is fuzzier, with supply chains crossing borders. An American academic, working in Geneva, argues that, while it might be difficult to help the losers, reversing the trend is even harder. The Man Who Knew: The Life and Times of Alan Greenspan.By Sebastian Mallaby. Penguin Press; 781 pages; $40. Bloomsbury; Â£25Once a hero, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve is now being called a villain. Sebastian Mallaby, who used to write for The Economist and is married to our editor-in-chief, Zanny Minton Beddoes, examines whether Alan Greenspan was to blame for the financial crisis. Winner of the Financial Times and McKinsey Business Book of the Year award 2016. Alibaba: The House That Jack Ma BuiltBy Duncan Clark. Ecco; 287 pages; $27.99 and Â£18.99An intriguing insiderâ€™s account of how Jack Ma conquered Chinaâ€™s internet, by an early adviser to the company Eccentric Orbits: The Iridium StoryBy John Bloom. Atlantic Monthly Press; 537 pages; $27.50. Grove Press; Â£16.99The exhaustive (and exhausting) tale of the Iridium communications project and how it was brought back from the dead. Culture, society and travelCleverlands: The Secrets Behind the Success of the Worldâ€™s Education SuperpowersBy Lucy Crehan. Unbound; 304 pages; Â£16.99Too much writing about education is polemical and ill-informed. Lucy Crehanâ€™s book is refreshingly fair-minded and makes a case that there is a lot to learn about how other countries learn. Free Speech: Ten Principles for a Connected WorldBy Timothy Garton Ash. Yale University Press; 491 pages; $30. Atlantic; Â£20How urbanisation and the spread of the internet has increased the possibilities of freedom of expression, but also the consequences that stem from it. A distillation of a lifetimeâ€™s research and writing, by the Oxford academic who also created freespeechdebate.com. Another Day in the Death of America: A Chronicle of Ten Short LivesBy Gary Younge. Nation Books; 267 pages; $25.99. Guardian Faber; Â£16.99The stories of ten young people who were shot and killed on the arbitrarily selected date of Saturday November 23rd 2013. A â€œlong, doleful, piercing cryâ€, by a journalist on the Guardian, in a country so overwhelmed by gun violence that it has almost given up trying to stop it. The Life Project: The Extraordinary Story of Our Ordinary LivesBy Helen Pearson. Soft Skull; 256 pages; $17.95 Penguin; Â£9.99How a random, nationwide sample of people linked only by their birth in 1946 has been followed by researchers and data-gatherers, and helped shape public policy across the country. A jewel in the crown of British social science. Meetings with Remarkable ManuscriptsBy Christopher de Hamel. Allen Lane; 632 pages; Â£30The politics and meaning of medieval manuscripts. A delightful and surprising book, by the man who has examined more manuscripts than anyone before him. Progress: Ten Reasons to Look Forward to the FutureBy Johan Norberg. Oneworld; 246 pages; $24.99 and Â£16.99A Swedish economic historian studies the many, and often surprising, ways in which human life has improved. The End of Karma: Hope and Fury Among Indiaâ€™s YoungBy Somini Sengupta. Norton; 244 pages; $26.95 and Â£18.99How Indiaâ€™s youth are trading fatalism and karma for free will and higher expectations, by a former New York Times New Delhi bureau chief who interweaves data, first-hand accounts and archival research to great effect. City of Thorns: Nine Lives in the Worldâ€™s Largest Refugee CampBy Ben Rawlence. Picador; 384 pages; $26. Portobello; Â£14.99A chronicle of life in Dadaab refugee camp in northern Kenya, which was supposed to close in November, but hasnâ€™t because its inhabitants have nowhere to go. Beethoven for a Later Age: Living with the String QuartetsBy Edward Dusinberre. University of Chicago Press; 232 pages; $30. Faber & Faber; Â£18.99The lead violinist of the Takacs Quartet recounts its membersâ€™ musical lives, interweaving into the groupâ€™s autobiography the story of Beethovenâ€™s 16 string quartets, which are now regarded as the apogee of the chamber-music repertoire. How to Listen to Jazz By Ted Gioia. Basic Books; 272 pages; $24.99 and Â£16.99Why jazz is unique, and how to distinguish good jazz from bad. No author could have done a better job. FictionThe VegetarianBy Han Kang. Translated by Deborah Smith. Hogarth; 192 pages; $21. Portobello; Â£8.99This slim novella from South Korea is one of the most erotic literary novels of the season. Winner of the 2016 Man Booker International prize. War and TurpentineBy Stefan Hertmans. Translated by David McKay. Pantheon; 304 pages; $26.95. Harvill Secker; Â£16.99A lovingly reimagined life of an ordinary man whose life was for ever marked by the first world war. Fine prose from a Flemish-Belgian poet and essayist. The Mandibles: A Family, 2029-2047By Lionel Shriver. Harper; 400 pages; $27.99. Borough Press; Â£16.99A hilarious, and often brutal, tale of how one family fares when Americaâ€™s economy collapses. In God they trusted. By the irrepressible author of â€œWe Need to Talk About Kevinâ€. Swing TimeBy Zadie Smith. Penguin Press; 453 pages; $27. Hamish Hamilton; Â£18.99A powerful story of lives marred by secrets, unfulfilled potential and the unjustness of the world. This may well be Zadie Smithâ€™s finest novel. Science and technologyI Contain Multitudes: The Microbes Within Us and a Grander View of LifeBy Ed Yong. Ecco; 368 pages; $27.99. Bodley Head; Â£20A science writer and blogger turns an enthusiastic naturalistâ€™s eye on the bacteria, viruses and other minuscule organisms that cohabit the bodies of humans and other animals. Get to know some little-known villainsâ€”and many heroes. The Gene: An Intimate HistoryBy Siddhartha Mukherjee. Scribner; 592 pages; $32. Bodley Head; Â£25The world is wholly unprepared for the birth of the first human with a genome that has been permanently modified in a lab. By a Pulitzer-winning writer and physician. Patient HM: A Story of Memory, Madness, and Family SecretsBy Luke Dittrich. Random House; 440 pages; $28. Chatto & Windus; Â£18.99Patient HM became famous in the history of science when a surgeon treated his epilepsy by removing the medial temporal lobes in his brain, causing him to lose most of his memory. A remarkable examination of how neuroscience works, by the surgeonâ€™s grandson. Cure: A Journey into the Science of Mind over BodyBy Jo Marchant. Crown; 320 pages; $26. Canongate; Â£16.99A thought-provoking exploration of how the mind affects the body and can be harnessed to help treat physical illness, by an award-winning science journalist. The Glass Universe: How the Ladies of the Harvard Observatory Took the Measure of the StarsBy Dava Sobel. Viking; 336 pages; $30. To be published in Britain by Fourth Estate in January 2017The hidden history of the remarkable women whose contribution to astronomy changed our understanding of the stars and manâ€™s place in the universe, by the prize-winning author of â€œLongitudeâ€ and â€œGalileoâ€™s Daughterâ€. Our policy is to identify the reviewer of any book by or about someone closely connected with The Economist. Sebastian Mallaby is married to Zanny Minton Beddoes, our editor-in-chief. The review of his book in these pages (â€œMan in the Dockâ€, Oct 1st) was written by Martin Wolf, chief economics commentator of the Financial Times. It was edited for length only.

Greggå‰SUNæ€§èƒ½å·¥ç¨‹å¸ˆï¼Œæœ€æ—©çš„DTraceç”¨æˆ·ï¼Œå‡ºç‰ˆäº†åŒ…æ‹¬ã€Šæ€§èƒ½ä¹‹å·…ã€‹åœ¨å†…çš„ä¸€å¤§æ‰¹ä¹¦ç±ï¼Œå›Šæ‹¬äº†æ€§èƒ½é—®é¢˜é¢†åŸŸçš„æŠ€æœ¯ã€å·¥å…·ã€æ–¹æ³•è®ºç­‰æ–¹æ–¹é¢é¢ã€‚ä»–æ˜¯åŠ¨æ€è¿½è¸ªæŠ€æœ¯å½“ä¹‹æ— the proxy? Firstly, the proxy allows metrics to be filtered, reducing the amount of data logged and increasing the scaleability of the Ganglia collector. Secondly, sFlow-RT generates traffic flow metrics, making them available to Ganglia. Finally, an industry might agree to establish a uniform set of cyber-security standards, along with monitoring and enforcement mechanisms to ensure that all members are implementing the agreed-upon measures. smaller than 1024 bits (the current minimumis 768 bits) Several ciphers will be disabled by default: blowfish-cbc,cast128-cbc, all arcfour variants and the rijndael-cbc aliasesfor AES. MD5-based HMAC algorithms will be disabled by default. å»¶ä¼¸ï¼šLogjam Attackï¼ˆæœ¬äººæ²¡æŸ¥åˆ°å¯¹åº”çš„ä¸­æ–‡åç§°ï¼Œæš‚ç¿»è¯‘ä¸ºâ€œåƒµå°¸æ”»å‡»â€ï¼Œæ¬¢è¿ŽæŒ‡æ­£ï¼‰ä¸€ç§é’ˆå¯¹Diffie-Hellmanå¯†é’¥äº¤æ¢æŠ€æœ¯å‘èµ·çš„æ”»å‡»ï¼Œè€Œè¿™é¡¹æŠ€æœ¯åº”ç”¨äºŽè¯¸å¤šæµè¡Œçš„åŠ å¯†åè®®ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚HTTPSã€TLSã€SMTPSã€SSHåŠå…¶ä»–åè®®ã€‚ä¸€ä¸ªå›½å¤–è®¡ç®—æœºç§‘å­¦å®¶å›¢é˜Ÿ2015-5-20å…¬å¼€å‘å¸ƒã€‚ å»¶ä¼¸ï¼šå¼€æºç»„ä»¶æ¼”è¿›è¿½è¸ªæœ¬æ¡ˆä¾‹å®žé™…æ“ä½œè¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­ï¼Œå¼€å¤´èµ°äº†å¾ˆå¤šå¼¯è·¯ï¼Œå¹¶æ²¡æœ‰ä¸€ä¸‹æ‰¾åˆ°è¦å®³ã€‚æ ¹æºåœ¨äºŽå›¢é˜Ÿç¼ºä¹å…³æ³¨å¼€æºäº§å“æ¼”è¿›æ–¹å‘çš„æ„è¯†å’Œä¹ æƒ¯ï¼Œä¹Ÿç¼ºä¹ç›´æŽ¥é˜…è¯»ã€ç†è§£å®˜æ–¹æ–‡æ¡£çš„ä¹ æƒ¯ã€‚ OpenSSH 7.0 å˜æ›´è¯´æ˜ŽChanges since OpenSSH 6.9This focus of this release is primarily to deprecate weak, legacyand/or unsafe cryptography.Securityâ€”â€”â€“ sshd(8): OpenSSH 6.8 and 6.9 incorrectly set TTYs to be world-writable. Local attackers may be able to write arbitrary messagesto logged-in users, including terminal escape sequences.Reported by Nikolay Edigaryev. sshd(8): Portable OpenSSH only: Fixed a privilege separationweakness related to PAM support. Attackers who could successfullycompromise the pre-authentication process for remote codeexecution and who had valid credentials on the host couldimpersonate other users. Reported by Moritz Jodeit. sshd(8): Portable OpenSSH only: Fixed a use-after-free bugrelated to PAM support that was reachable by attackers who couldcompromise the pre-authentication process for remote codeexecution. Also reported by Moritz Jodeit. sshd(8): fix circumvention of MaxAuthTries using keyboard-interactive authentication. By specifying a long, repeatingkeyboard-interactive â€œdevicesâ€ string, an attacker could requestthe same authentication method be tried thousands of times ina single pass. The LoginGraceTime timeout in sshd(8) and anyauthentication failure delays implemented by the authenticationmechanism itself were still applied. Found by Kingcope. Potentially-incompatible Changes Support for the legacy SSH version 1 protocol is disabled bydefault at compile time. Support for the 1024-bit diffie-hellman-group1-sha1 key exchangeis disabled by default at run-time. It may be re-enabled usingthe instructions athttp://www.openssh.com/legacy.html Support for ssh-dss, ssh-dss-cert-* host and user keys is disabledby default at run-time. These may be re-enabled using theinstructions at http://www.openssh.com/legacy.html Support for the legacy v00 cert format has been removed. The default for the sshd_config(5) PermitRootLogin option has changed from â€œyesâ€ to â€œprohibit-passwordâ€. PermitRootLogin=without-password/prohibit-password now bans allinteractive authentication methods, allowing only public-key,hostbased and GSSAPI authentication (previously it permitted keyboard-interactive and password-less authentication if those were enabled). è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼ˆç¿»è¯‘ï¼‰OpenSSHå®žçŽ°äº†æ‰€æœ‰ç¬¦åˆSSHæ ‡å‡†çš„åŠ entry.content: æ‘˜è¦ 1.1 å¦‚ä½•é˜…è¯»æºç ï¼Ÿ 1.2 ç¨‹åºå‘½åè§„èŒƒ ä¸€ã€å¦‚ä½•é˜…è¯»æºç ï¼Ÿ1.1 é˜…è¯»æºç çš„ä¸€èˆ¬æµç¨‹ åˆ’åˆ†æ ¸å¿ƒå­ç³»ç»Ÿï¼ˆeg: Linux kernel è¿›ç¨‹ç®¡ç†å­ç³»ç»Ÿã€æ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†å­ç³»ç»Ÿï¼‰ åˆ†æžä¸»è¦æ•°æ®ç»“æž„ ï¼ˆç»“æž„ä½“ï¼‰ å…³é”®ç¨‹åºåˆ—è¡¨(åŠ è½½é¡ºåº,è°ƒç”¨å…³ç³»call flow,æ¶ˆæ¯ä¼ é€’è·¯å¾„ï¼Œæ€§èƒ½æ¶ˆè€—ï¼‰ ä¸»é¢˜å¼æŽ¢ç´¢ã€å¸¦ç€ç›®çš„åˆ†æžå®žä¾‹ï¼ˆeg: Linux æ”¯æŒé—°ç§’å—ï¼Ÿï¼‰ æŠ€èƒ½æé«˜çš„ç§˜è¯€ï¼šè¿«äºŽéœ€è¦çš„å­¦ä¹ ã€‚ Problem Domain Model Arch & Implement Improvement Best Practice é¡¹ç›®ã€æ¡†æž¶å’Œå…³é”®æ€§æ¦‚å¿µ Architecture Key Concept â€”â€“ é—®é¢˜æ¨¡åž‹åŒ–ã€éªŒè¯Demo â€”â€“ â€”â€“ æ¡†æž¶ä¸ºåº”ç”¨è€Œç”Ÿï¼šå¹³è¡¡æŠ€æœ¯å®žçŽ°ã€ä¸šåŠ¡åº”ç”¨ã€é¡¹ç›® 1.2 ç¨‹åºå‘½åè§„èŒƒ The most important consistency rules are those that govern naming. The style of a name immediately informs us what sort of thing the named entity is: a type, a variable, a function, a constant, a macro, etc., without requiring us to search for the declaration of that entity. The pattern-matching engine in our brains relies a great deal on these naming rules. Naming rules are pretty arbitrary, but we feel that consistency is more important than individual preferences in this area, so regardless of whether you find them sensible or not, the rules are the rules. ", request_nbr); } zmq_close (requester); zmq_ctx_destroy (context); return 0;} 12345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728293031323334353637383940414243444546MakefileSHELL = /bin/shprefix = /usr/localexec_prefix=${prefix}srcdir = .sbindir = ${exec_prefix}/sbinlibdir = ${exec_prefix}/libsysconfdir = ${prefix}/etcSETUPDIR = /home/nmsTARGETDIR = $(SETUPDIR)/binSRCDIR = .CC = gccCFLAGS = -O2 -WallCPPFLAGS= -g DEFS = LDFLAGS = LIBS = -lzmq -L/usr/local/libINCLUDES= -I/usr/local/include CURR_DIR = $(shell pwd)CC_TMP = libOBJS = $(CC_TMP)/veto_mq_server.o $(CC_TMP)/veto_mq_utils.oTARGET = veto_mq_server.c.o: $(CC) -I. $(CPPFLAGS) $(DEFS) $(CFLAGS) -c $<all: $(TARGET)$(TARGET): $(OBJS) $(CC) $(CPPFLAGS) $(OBJS) $(LIBS) $(LDFLAGS) -o $@ -cp $(SRCDIR)/$(TARGET) $(TARGETDIR)/$(TARGET) -chmod ugo+s $(TARGETDIR)/$(TARGET) -chmod ugo+s $(SRCDIR)/$(TARGET) clean: -rm -f *.o *~ *.core core $(TARGET) -rm -f $(TARGETDIR)/$(TARGET)veto_mq_server.o: veto_mq_server.c $(CC) -g -c -o $(CC_TMP)/veto_mq_server.o veto_mq_server.c $(CPPFLAGS) $(INCLUDES)veto_mq_utils.o: veto_mq_utils.c $(CC) -g -c -o $(CC_TMP)/veto_mq_utils.o veto_mq_utils.c $(INCLUDES) Running1234bash-3.2# ./veto_mq_serverbash-3.2# ps -ef | grep mq | grep -v 'grep' 0 3616 1 0 10:00AM ttys000 0:00.01 ./veto_mq_server 12345678910bash-3.2# ./veto_mq_clientConnecting to hello world server...Sending Hello 0...Received World 0Sending Hello 1...Received World 1Sending Hello 2...Received World 2Sending Hello 3...Received World 3 å‚è€ƒæ–‡çŒ® ï¼ˆæŽ¨èï¼‰ï¼»ç¾Žï¼½Pieter Hintjensã€ŠZeroMQ:Messaging for Many Applicationsã€‹ ZeroMQç¤¾åŒºç”Ÿæ€ç™½çš®ä¹¦ æ·±å…¥è§£æžä¸­é—´ä»¶ä¹‹RocketMQ
